source.title: Isolation of monomeric Rab10 (1-181) by Size Exclusion Chromatography

source.description: Equilibrate a Superdex 75 HiPrep (XK 16/60) column in SEC buffer I.

source.body: The recovered, untagged Rab10 is a mix of aggregated Rab10 (MW > 100 kDa), Thrombin (native Mw 37 kDa) and monomeric Rab10 1-181 (Mw 22.9 kDa).

source.title: Isolation of monomeric Rab10 (1-181) by Size Exclusion Chromatography

source.description:
Apply the digested Rab10 sample either in 2 x
or as 1 x
to the column and develop the column at a flowrate of
.

source.body: We normally observe a substantial amount of protein eluting at the void volume and thereafter.

source.title: Isolation of monomeric Rab10 (1-181) by Size Exclusion Chromatography

source.description:
However, seperate the monomeric Rab10 from these aggregates and contaminants and elutes at around
(Figure 1). Collect the fractions of this peak.

source.body: We normally obtain – of monomeric Rab10 from such preparation from of bacterial culture.

source.title: Isolation of monomeric Rab10 (1-181) by Size Exclusion Chromatography

source.description: Pool and concentrate the protein using Amicon Ultra 3000 Da MWCO filters.

source.body: The protein tolerates concentration to and more. It can be frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at .

source.title: Phosphorylation

source.description:
Mix
(
of Rab10 protein at
) in SEC buffer I with
of His-MST3 protein (
),
Tris
(
f.c.),
MgCl2 (
f.c.), and
ATP (
f.c.) and incubate at
for
–
.

source.body: In order to produce of phosphorylated Rab10, it is necessary to phosphorylate - of purified Rab10 protein and then repurify the phosphorylated species. Hence the Rab10 protein from of bacterial culture is required and must be prepared first. We combine the Rab10 protein from three preparations for this purpose.

source.title: Phosphorylation

source.description:
After the phosphorylation reaction is completed, remove the kinase by depletion over a
Ni-agarose bed.

source.body: Although MST3 is not a very potent Rab10 kinase, 90% of the Rab protein does become phosphorylated in these conditions.
Some losses occur, but of phosphorylated Rab10 can be recovered.

source.title: Repurification and buffer exchange by Size Exclusion Chromatography

source.description: Apply the protein to a Superdex 75 column, equilibrate this time in SEC buffer II.

source.body: This step removes the ATP and ADP, any remaining MST3 and replaces the buffer system. There are two important changes compared to SEC buffer I: firstly the buffer system is MES at and not Tris at . This is to protonise the Rab10 protein in preparation for the next cation exchange step and Tris is not a suitable buffer system for cation exchange chromatography. Secondly, SEC buffer II does not contain L-arginine, which would interfere with the subsequent cation-exchange step. Figure 2 shows that the pRab10 protein elutes at , exactly where the Rab10 would elute.

source.title: Chromatography on a Source 15 S HR10/10 column to separate phospho species

source.description: In order to separate the phospho species from each other and from the remaining unphosphorylated protein, employ cation exchange chromatography using a Source 15 S column.

source.title: Chromatography on a Source 15 S HR10/10 column to separate phospho species

source.description:
To this end, pack an empty HR10/10 or GL 10/100 column with
Source 15 S resin and use vacuum suction to obtain a homogenous well packed resin bed.

source.body: Ion exchange chromatography is a concentrating method, hence the load volume is not critical.

source.title: Chromatography on a Source 15 S HR10/10 column to separate phospho species

source.description: Therefore, dilute the monomeric Rab10 sample into the Low Salt buffer to reduce the ionic strength sufficiently for the protein to bind.

source.title: Chromatography on a Source 15 S HR10/10 column to separate phospho species

source.description: Equilibrate the Source 15 S HR10/10 with the IEX- buffers using an Äkta Pure or Purifier.

source.title: Chromatography on a Source 15 S HR10/10 column to separate phospho species

source.description: Dilute the pRab10 protein isolated from the gel filtration step tenfold into the IEX-Low Salt buffer.

source.title: Chromatography on a Source 15 S HR10/10 column to separate phospho species

source.description:
Apply aliquots equivalent to
to the S-column at a flowrate of
.

source.body: Two column runs may be necessary.

source.title: Chromatography on a Source 15 S HR10/10 column to separate phospho species

source.description:
Develop the column at the same flow rate with a shallow
gradient to 30% IEX-High Salt buffer collecting
fractions.

source.body: Generally, up to four peaks are resolved see Figure 3. The dominant peak eluting at 15 mS/cm (here ) represents single phosphorylated Rab10.

source.title: Chromatography on a Source 15 S HR10/10 column to separate phospho species

source.description: Pool the fractions containing pRab10 protein.

source.body: Protein yield should exceed .

source.description:

or GDP to
as required.

source.title: Quality control

source.description:
Separate
of the protein on a 4% - 20% Tris Glycine SDS-polyacrylamid gel and stain with Instant Blue (Figure 4a).

source.body: The protein should be >95% homogeneous.

source.title: Quality control

source.description:
Separate a
of unphosphorylated Rab10 (1-181) and
of unphosphorylated Rab10 (1-181) on a 12% Phos-tag SDS-Polyacrylamid gel that separates phosphorylated and non-phosphorylated Rab proteins, run as described previously (Ito et al. 2016) (Figure 4b).

source.body: The migration of the phosphorylated and non-phosphorylated pRab10 proteins can clearly be distinguished.

description: Rab10 (Uniprot: P61026), a membrane associated small GTPase, likely involved in vesicle trafficking, has been identified as one of the substrates of the Leucine Rich Repeat Kinase 2 (LRRK2; Uniprot Q5S007)) and the Protein Phosphatase PPM1H (Uniprot Q9ULR3) (Steger et al., 2016; Berndsen et al., 2019). In order to perform detailed studies of Rab10 phosphorylation and dephosphorylation, it is necessary to produce milligram amounts of pure, stoichiometrically phosphorylated Rab10 protein. The full-length sequence of Rab10 is very prone to aggregation and precipitation when expressed in bacteria, resulting in extremely low yields of protein, even when solubilising tags are employed for the expression of fusion proteins. A shorter fragment, spanning residues 1-181 is much more useful for bacterial expression. Here we describe in detail the method we use to produce milligram quantities of stoichiometrically Thr73 phosphorylated Rab10[1-181]. We employ the MST3 kinase to phosphorylate recombinant Rab10 at Thr73, because MST3 is much easier and less expensive to produce or purchase than LRRK2 (Berndsen et al., 2019, Vieweg et al. 2020).
